.1 and .3 are part of the problem.
.2 is all that matters.

It doesn't matter what your track record or qualification, people are prone to mistakes ... even worse, people have agendas.
It doesn't matter how many truthful articles you write, you can always write a biased nonfactual one, mistakenly or intentionally.
At the same time it doesn't matter how many biased and false articles you write, you can write a truthful one.

All that matters are the facts:
If you publish/share something that's true, nothing else matters - the information is correct.
If you publish something false, nothing else matters - the information is incorrect.

At the point where you bring in any other quality apart from facts or evidence... or a qualifying argument based on the evidence, your information becomes propaganda.

.3 may at least sometimes be a method to corroborate the facts, if another news article has some source that agrees with yours... this simply translates to .2
.1 is useless and irrelevant.

Few issues with just trusting 'reputable sources': Carl Bernstein himself published an article in The Rolling Stones titled 'The CIA and the Media' - it was not published in a 'reputable source' because it was a conflict of interest and shed a negative light on their individual organizations as well as the corporate media establishment. Research the Church Committee Hearings and the CIA Operation Mockingbird that was uncovered (with little cooperation from people like George H. Bush, who was a previous Director of the CIA).
Research the Smith-Mundt Modernization Act and how propaganda was made legal - press releases from the White House can be inserted into public broadcasting stations and be circulated without any fact-checking.
Censorship is also another issue - just 'Googling' something is not going to automatically verify authentic evidence either - their search algorithms are designed in an extremely complex way, which I don't fully understand myself, it goes back to the problem of blindly trusting reputable sources - Google is a corporation, we can even say media is one of its functions because it is a source for news, information and video content like YouTube.
Ad Revenue, Synergy with other business partners, their own political ideas (and yes Google does have them if you research James Damore and he's just one example) can affect what they would put up at the top of a search engine - you can even pay google to make your searches easier to find by pushing it to the front pages.
Read Edward Bernay's book 'Propaganda', he was the father of Public Relations and Advertising in the US, someone who is often called America's more successful Joseph Goebbels. If you don't want to read the entire book, at least read his most famous quote from it.
Also, Read Manufacturing Consent by Noam Chomsky, and 'Five Filters of Mass Media' by him and Ed Herman, also called the 'Propaganda Model'

Having studied journalism myself in University, everything Katie Byron is saying is what was taught to me. Most things I just mentioned above, apart from Ed Bernays and Noam Chomsky, are things I learned on my own and would never be taught at Universities or Schools - the relevant literature I've mentioned is sufficient to explain why this is.
There is a psychological phenomenon called 'cognitive ease' that makes you trust familiar sources with less scrutiny, even if you're a credible 15-year journalist - she did say 'Oh NASA, that's always good', 'WashingtonPost, that looks good' even though The Washington Post has been bought out by Amazon, and has suffered many scandals over the years. This is essentially how confirmation bias works.
Not to say that you shouldn't trust scientific institutions like NASA, although many scientific institutions can also have different results, but science is usually more trustworthy than news organizations. Also, double-check to see what their evidence is - if experiments were conducted - if they tested every hypothesis - did they suffer experimenter's bias and discount ones without giving a valid reason?
Sadly, it isn't as simple as just googling something - you have to be extremely thorough with any investigation and inquiry and also know the literature and history about media, misinformation, propaganda and the ability to use psychological manipulation on mass scales. When you're not an expert in a field you're trying to research you do have to believe what they are saying is correct, and usually having corroborating sources is good, but is sometimes also a logical fallacy - 'argumentum ad populum' or appeal to popularity.

Actually the problem of good and bad news was already discussed in ancient times. Once a man approached Socrates and said "Socrates! I must tell you something about one of your students!" "Wait a second!" - replied the philosopher - "before you say that, I have to run the information through a 3-step filter. Firstly, are you sure if it is true?" - "Well, no, I heard it from a guy who heard it from a guy..." - "All right then, if this information would be true, would it benefit me in some way?" - "No, I don't think so." - "Well then, does this information at least put my student in a good light?" - "No, on the contrary." - "So let me recapitulate. You don't know if your story is true, it would have no use to me and could falsely slander one of my students. Therefore, I do not wish to hear it."
The above story shows that Socrates was a great philosopher. It also explains why he never learned that his wife had an affair with Plato.

That is a real picture of Woodward and Bernstein watching Nixon, but it's from April 30th, 1973, more than a year before Nixon resigned. Nixon was probably still calling them liars at that point. The way I found this original photo is with the TinEye image search, which usually finds the original source much better than Google.

(To more easily find the original image that I'm talking about, you can search for its caption: "Washington DC: April 30, 1973. Washington Post reporters Carl Bernstein (chair) and Bob Woodward watch Richard Nixon speaking on TV. Watergate scandal. ©Mark Godfrey / The Image Works")

By the way, you guys were also using the Google Image Search wrong - you have to click on the "all sizes" link to actually narrow down the results of the image search, since otherwise you'll just be looking at search results that Google is guessing to be related to the picture, e.g. by keywords.

As someone else said, it's not necessarily about the facts. People will frequently deny facts even when given irrefutable proof. The problem is that people want to continue believing what they believe. People are not taught that it's ok to be wrong. That it's ok to change your mind about something. That it's ok to make mistakes (and then learn from them). Instead, people are taught you have to be right, no matter the cost. Then you couple that with the parasympathetic nervous system (fight, flight, freeze, friend response) and you get an arrogant tribalistic territorialism about facts and beliefs. It's also now been shown that the more fearful you make people feel about something, the more extreme they become in their beliefs. No amount of teaching people how to discern facts and think critically is going to help until there is a culture change in HOW people think about themselves and others. (i.e. people need to learn how to eat more humble pie, be more compassionate AND think critically)

Truth is not an absolute. Humans tend to believe the truth is what is most aligned with what our synapses have recorded over our lives.  We seek online things that match what our brains have already recorded.  7 centuries ago the truth was the earth is flat. Today the majority accept that it is not flat, but there is still a substantial population that believe it is not( a lot of people call them crackpots).  Personally, until I go around the earth and see it for myself, I believe I don’t really know for sure (absolutely).  I’m and Engineer also. I tend to believe what I can measure or see myself, but ci also have experienced times when my eyes have lied to me.  What I do know is that it is easier for me to believe things that align with what my brain has already observed.  I could decide to trust someone (journalist,Facebook employees) to tell me what the truth is, but then that truth is only what aligns with what their brains have recorded.  They are not necessarily malicious, they believe, but that doesn’t make it true.  The video basically defines truth as what most people believe after employees of a few companies decide to let our brains record.

0:26 « truth is truth, it is a separate thing » Well... Things are more subtle than that. Truth is not a separate thing. Truth is always related to a community. Such question should be regarded as pointless in essence: everyone is right... in his own community.
This is not to say that everything is true given the right reference. There are countless of informations reported here and there which are totally wrong but be careful: truth is a human thing. Not a divine one. And like all human things, it is complex.

Another factor that muddies the water is selective hypothesising or theorising. It’s when someone takes a correlation they find within a group of statistics, interprets the evidence through their initial assumptions and then reaches a conclusion. It’s a significant issue within universities and academia nowadays. It’s a technique of research that is subtly influenced by bias. Generally it’s hidden behind the phrasing and/or the choice words and their meaning. The largest culprit school in Australian universities and academia is sociology.

3:04 this is a really good moment to mention how important it is to not make the "retweet" decision personal. It's about the content you're retweeting, not you.

It's obvious that the topic of the tweet was important to her. Similarly you might come across poor quality content that really speaks to something you care about. In such a case, rejecting that content can feel like you're rejecting yourself, or the importance of the topic that matters to you. But you're not!

If the image in the tweet is fake, and there's no sources, etc - it's just bad content. Not sharing it doesn't mean that the issue that matters to you isn't important. If you really need to you can go and look up reputable sources for that same topic and post that instead of retweeting the post with the fake image, for example.

So make sure not to make it personal when evaluating if something in your news feed is true or false.

Regarding the OODA loop, I understand the necessity for simplification due to the metaphor being presented. It is also the case that the OODA loop is not the main topic of this video, so a detailed discussion would not be appropriate. However; it is important to note that the OODA loop is not simply about speed. I don't have the best understanding of this topic myself, so I'll drop a (somewhat lengthy) quote from a paper titled, "Science, Strategy and War The Strategic Theory of John Boyd," by Frans Osinga. This appears on page 272.

"The first misconception [about the OODA loop] concerns the element of speed. The rapid OODA looping
idea suggests a focus on speed of decision making, and “out-looping” the opponent by going
through consecutive OODA cycles faster, but Boyd equally addresses the other aspect of
tempo; altering the tempo. Tempo makes it hard for the opponent to adequately adapt to the
fast changing situation. It is not absolute speed that counts; it is the relative tempo or a variety
in rhythm that counts. The OODA speed is a parameter to vary with for it is also a pattern
one can give away. This does not really imply that one should make up one’s mind slower,
but it may imply that, when it comes to the action part of the OODA loop, one may want to
alter the times of executing actions so as to foster the impression of unpredictability.
Changing OODA speed becomes part of denying a pattern to recognized."

My very basic, unscientific, stoic approach to news:
"An event happened, someone's commenting about it"

1-Does it has the potential to have a direct or indirect effect on me, either on the short or in the long term, but there's absolutely nothing I can do about it?
If yes, then that's life, stuff happens, there's nothing I can do about it.
If something can be done about it, then proceed to step 2.

2-Does it has the potential to have a direct effect on me on the short term (next hours, days) and there's something I can do about it?
If yes, adopt and engage in every conceivable scientific way to check for veracity and its true consequences.
If no, then don't worry about it or about checking for other sources and proceed to step 3.

3-Does it has the potential to have a direct effect on me in the long term (next weeks, months, years) or, an indirect effect, either on the short or in the long term and there's something I can do about it?
If yes, keep an eye for other sources commenting about it in the next days, weeks, months, years.
If no, then don't worry about it or about checking for other sources... it's probably something that it will affect other people too and the truth will emerge eventually if enough time and importance is given to it...

"Click restraint" is a great term for the solution to a concept I've been thinking about, which I call "click indulgence". It's is a problem that plagues internet users everywhere. One of the biggest problems, in my opinion, is that we're indoctrinating our youth into this click indulgent culture from such a young age. Children with smart phones are being given free reign on YouTube and social media, developing bad habits during times of youthful indiscretion. The environment we're exposing them to is not conducive to the thoughtful decision making we should be striving to teach them. Instead, they are encouraged to indulge their every whim and click indiscriminately. Even we as adults struggle with these problems, so I don't see why we think our children will be well served by cultivating the same bad habits.

John Boyd. There's a terrific biography on him and his battles with military bureaucracy. In response to the F-15 he countered with the F-16. Much cheaper to build and operate, just as effective. He had a terrific method of entering a debate (Congressional military allocations, etc). He would start by using only the data and the arguments of the people supporting the project he opposed. To prepare he'd go over all the numbers, as an engineer (Boyd was one) you'd really enjoy this book. One plane that was being over-promoted he ran the numbers and figured out that if the numbers being submitted were true, then the plane's wings had positive lift numbers when velocity was zero. When he was told about the F-111 proposal, configurable wings, he accurately predicted the added weight, lost speed and range caused by the hinge.

You never said, 'books' (that's okay, it's my hobbyhorse, not yours) Reading, even reading fiction, develops your mind like nothing else (except maybe painful experience). Hopefully some of my nonsense here is proof. Go back in the NYTimes and look at the front page articles written by Judith Miller about Weapons of Mass Destruction in Iraq prior to the US Invasion in 2003. How many paragraphs did it take you to either trust or begin to mistrust the story? Life and history and the news are really really complicated, but with experience, lots of reading and thinking, some things will just seem obvious--and you can make money from them. You have to approach the news with your own questions. Example: I'm not real fond of our current president, a couple of months ago I read that the Democratic majority Congress may be able to subpoena his taxes and make them public. I don't know if they can actually do this, but if they can, the important first question is, Why haven't they done it already? If they can but haven't... then maybe the president and his party haven't been winning elections so much as the Democrats have been losing them. Should I next start speculating what might be in those tax records? What would be the point? It's idle speculation until there's information to speculate on.

Here are questions to guide your evaluation process:
Contributor/Author
Is the author well known and frequently published?
Are there any reviews available for the author's work?
How easy is it to find contact information for the author?
Publisher
Is the publisher well known and well respected in the industry? Do they have a website?
How selective is the publisher in determining what they publish?
Are they also the main retailer for what they publish?
Does their other content seem legitimate and credible?
Currency
When was the source originally published? When was it last updated?
Are you citing the latest version? If not, how does that affect your argument?
Accuracy
Does the argument the author makes appear anywhere else? Is it backed up with data or other sources?
Where does the information presented come from?
Are there grammatical or spelling errors? Any dead links?
Relevance
What is the tone of voice? Does it appeal more to an academic reader, or is it more casual?
Would someone not familiar with the subject be able to understand the source's topic after reading it?
What is the intended audience of the source? Is it similar or different from your intended audience?
Bias
If the source is a website, does the site have ads? Do they affect the content?
What is the purpose of the source? Is it to persuade or argue? To entertain or inform?
What is the author's tone of voice? Do they seem to only present one side of the argument? How do they address the counter argument, if at all?
Citations
Does the author give credit to sources where they received information and conducted research?
Do the sources they used seem legitimate?
What sources refer to the one you are using? Do those seem legitimate?
Reproduced
Is this the original source? Has it been reproduced?
If it was reproduced, when was that done? Who reproduced it? To what end?
If it was reproduced, does it have copyright information or information on the original source?
Complete
How much information can be learned from the source on a particular topic?
Does it talk about a broad topic, or a specific element of a topic?
Are there larger, more popular sources on the topic than this one?
Credible
After reading through the various questions above, does this source seem credible?

I've never shared false information in social networks because I do have kind of a protocol, first i chck who shared it, you probably don't want to share something from one of those "make a lot of followers sharing viral things" accounts, real journalists or big organizations are safer (but proceed with caution). Then of course you have to check the information, if it sounds too crazy or too exciting is probably overblown, always be skeptical, also if you're sharing an article, don't just share it for the title and image, open the articles and read it or at least do quick browsing of it, this is the first reason why people share incorrect things, they don't actually read what they shared. Then do a fast search for the same news or facts, if it's legit, there will be another publications from other reputable sources and let's not forget half-truths the artie can have real facts but then make exaggerated or wrong conclusions from it, and looking for other sources will help you avoid that. The rule of thumb is no matter what are your political views, always be skeptical, learn the facts and corroborate the information.

The day I stopped trusting the media: I was in the Army, at Ft. Drum NY (the 10th MTN Division).  Shortly after 9/11 - we had some troops deploy.  One of the Major News networks came on and said "The 10th MTN DIV is deploying to Afghanistan... Afghanistan has mountainous terrain... The 10th MTN DIV was chosen for their specialized Mountain warfare training."  This is a harmless fabrication, but a fabrication nonetheless.  FT. DRUM is on some seriously flat ground, no mountains anywhere in site.  The "Mountain Division" is a historical name for the unit that was actually started in Aspin Colorodao that actually did to Mountain warfare training.    The problem that I saw with this is that it was in fact fabricated, and only a small number of people would really even know that.  So, How many more things do they fabricate that most people (like me) would have no way to verify.  I mean, it all sounds good, but it's just fictitious.  How much easier would it be to make stuff up that happens in the white house, where only a few people in the world would actually know the truth?  Way too easy. One major problem you haven't addressed is the fact that our view of the world can be biased even when the information we receive is entirely factual. This is an often overlooked problem. For example, your view of how much crime there is or how much you are personally at risk, is typically built up over time based on stories you hear. But the reality is that actual crime statistics and threats bear little or no relation to the frequency of stories in the news - even when those stories are individually 100% accurate. This is because only a tiny fraction of actual crime events ever get reported. This bias applies to a very large proportion of our world view, how we view the country, economic models, political systems etc. Just spend some time watching news sources from a completely different country and culture and you will realize just how much your views are shaped by the culture of the news even when the actual stories are factually accurate.
As for your statement that there are good news sources out there, I don't know of any, do you? Every one I have tried is biased in some way. The best sources I have found are NOT news sources but channels like yours that cover a particular topic. One of the biggest problems with the media today is the funding model means they either are primarily interested in views (for which factual reporting is a detriment not a benefit) or they are funded for political reasons - which means there will be propaganda - or most often, both of the above. The very fact that all the big media is owned by rich people means an inherent bias towards the interests of the rich.

I'm not sure if you're aware, but there is a method called zetetic that apply the scientific method to investigate things. Usually it's for paranormal activities, but basically, it comes down to read and evaluate information with skepticism. It's the "art of the doubt". But it doesn't mean they don't believe in anything, it's just that they use the scientific method (with a hypothesis, experiments, conclusion if possible but not necessarily), without "a priori" on the topic. It's very interesting and it forces you to double check everything you're being told. It can be exhausting but if you don't want to be part of the problem, you don't really have a choice. Before, media were playing this role, but nowadays with the increasing speed of information diffusion, it's not really true anymore, sadly.

Education to media should be taught everywhere, but unfortunately, it isn't.

I took a Contemporary Media class in college and we covered a lot of this in the class. One of the biggest things I got from that class is the impact that even reading the title of an article has on your opinion and confirmation bias.

As an example: say you believe in global warming. If you were to scroll through and read the title of the global warming article they used and never open it, you wouldn’t be considering if that article was factual or not. You would be subconsciously telling yourself that the article is just more proof of global warming. So even just scrolling through your news feed can impact your biases.

Note, this comment has nothing to do with my opinion on global warming. It is just an example.

I think the main problem, apart from general ignorance of most internet users on HOW to verify what they're reading, is laziness.

We're now facing an era where to understand whether or not the information you're reading is true or false, you (sometimes) need to have a good grasp of the topic you're inspecting. Whether it's politics or science, you must now do the work that once was only the journalists'.
It's a lot easier to just let others do the thinking for you, rather than doing it yourself.
So what do most people end up doing? They go with the most popular opinions, and follow blindly who they think should do the thinking for them.

Your guest makes a mistake, herself. The reputation and credentials of a source are not sufficient to decide the value of that source's claims. It's evidence, but it's insufficient. Always be willing to listen and learn, and remember that you have your own areas of expertise and are most equipped to decide in those areas. I'm sure that GMOs are not the threat people think they are because that's in my area of expertise. I'm sure that vaccines are very effective in fighting a large number of deadly diseases because that's in my area of expertise.

However, that doesn't mean I should ignore any information that doesn't line up with my opinions in these areas. No, not even if it's from non-experts.

Let’s talk about the broken peer-review system next and the academic system in the hard sciences that now incentivizes fraudulent data or even publishing experiments that never took place. That and the issue of scooping. In an environment wherein universities now require academics to publish a large minimum number (~6+) of papers per academic year just to keep their job for the next year, there has been a SIGNIFICANT rise in fraud taking place in the biological and chemical sciences and no one is talking about it and the “civilian” population at large who places so much faith in science do not know this is happening and are often believing sometimes sensationalized media stories about “discoveries” that have not actually been verified by any sources outside the potentially biased laboratory in which these experiments were done. Sometimes bias makes it into science by accident but it has become extremely noticeable that the more nefarious injection of bias is increasing.

In short, let’s have a discussion about the deeply flawed present peer-review system wherein experiments aren’t even repeated by a second or third source for veracity. If repeatability is key then we should perhaps have an organization that hires organic/synthetic chemists, biochemist, analytical and physical chemists, cellular/molecular biologists, etc etc whose sole purpose is to repeat experimentation submitted for publication. In organic synthesis I have encountered papers which I have drawn upon and found that their product was absolutely not what they claimed, whether it was an error in their analysis of their NMR, IR and Mass Spec spectrograph(s) or improper experimental methodology no one can know but let’s be honest and ask WHY we don’t see papers getting published in journals that have a negative outcome to the hypothesis after experimentation, that is just as important to discovery and science; although it’s rarely about discovery anymore, it’s all about money/funding,fighting for tenure positions nowadays, science has become “for sale” often to the highest bidder, whether you are contracted by a pharmaceutical giant or local CRO or government program or in some cases even an agency whose political agenda depends on a VERY specific outcome.....

Also, let’s stop coming up with fantasies and fairytales that have no empirical evidence to support that assertion and stick to data driven science..... LOOKING AT YOU BIOLOGISTS, ANTHROPOLOGISTS, PALEONTOLOGISTS, ARCHAEOLOGISTS. Even astrophysicists have become susceptible to this baloney as of late.

Great post, but I disagree with your root cause analysis. The real problem is not so much "fake news," but true-but-filtered news. Someone who gets his news from a biased source, liberal or conservative, may have 100% true facts, but facts telling only half the story. Case in point: I once noted to a friend that President Obama had been reversed UNANIMOUSLY by the Supreme Court 13 times, a stunning statistic since the Supreme Court hardly ever does anything unanimously. He called that "fake news," we went back and forth, and eventually verified the statistic. But what struck me is that he is an extremely well-read and intelligent person. He spends hours every day making sure he's fully informed. But his news sources (things like the NY Times and the Washington Post) weren't keeping a tally of Obama reversals and displaying them prominently, but mine were. Our assessments of President Obama were totally different, even though we both were getting true facts. I'm curious to know what you, or the Poynter Institute, recommends to solve that problem. (Incidentally, there is a good response to this "fact," namely that several of the cases originated under President Bush, and one can't fairly tag Obama with all of them. The point is, though, that one has to have the fact in order to fairly evaluate it, something that occurs through some sources but not others.)

it's a neverending cycle though... who factchecks the factcheckers? but before we even get to that next-level meta, can primary factcheckers even factcheck fast enough?

at the current phase, it's mostly a matter of volume and limited time, and already trolls would thrash factcheckers cos they can churn out low quality fakes way faster and at almost no cost to themselves.

in the next phase, as the "factcheck wars" ramp up and more establishment or independent orgs decide they should fund more factcheckers, the fakers can ramp up the quality of fakes, which would cost a bit more time/money but exponentially increase the cost of uncovering them.

it's a losing war against fakes... and we're not even in deep fake territory yet. in the end, it's just cheaper for society as a whole to ignore viral stuff on social media. they're no different than spam you get in your email. people need to be taught not to blindly believe anything -- even if it's from "verified" sources or "official" sources. only primary sources with a long history of reliability should deserve any trust. every secondary source has its own particular bias, and that bias MUST be factored in.

Another clue that one can use is the question of whether the site make glib and sweeping generalizations such as NASA lies vs specific allegations of lying based on verifiable facts such as this image as been doctored as one can see from examining this the original image.

Also, sometimes speculation about motives are relevant as factors but hot as evidence. Thus one might speculate that a person lied to hide their crime as a reason for them lying but merely accusing them of lying is not a proof that they lied.

As such if the proof of lying is that the one might have a motive for lying then that is a poor proof in that just because someone may have some potential motive to lie that does not mean they will lie. But if one has actual evidence that someone has lied the one might speculate on why they may have do so and thus possible speculate on their motives based on that evidence that they did indeed lie.

For example here is an example My smith is a layer and all lawyers lie and Mr Smith has every reason to lie. vs Mt smith said this before and now is saying the opposite indicating that he may have lied and perhaps the reason he did so is to cover up that thing he was trying to hide.

The former is a glib generalization followed by trying to back up the claim that the person lied because they had something to gain from lying while the latter uses evidence to support that the person lied and then based on tha5t evidence speculated on why that person may have been so motivated to do so, not as proof but rather as an explanation based on other proofs that they may have lied..

With the verification of what we see online, we also do need to remember where we are and what we're doing. If I retweet Velociraptor Earth (parody of Flat Earth that asserts the planet is shaped like a velociraptor), obviously what I'm retweeting isn't real, but it's also not meant to be. My followers either know that, or they're a stranger who followed me and it's their own fault if they're that stupid. You, however, can't afford to retweet a parody without calling it out as a parody because you have mostly followers you don't know and have a responsibility towards even the ones who can't discern what many of us see as "obvious jokes" from reality.


For the average person, the larger issue is passing false information to friends who carry on the chain or get upset or hurt by it. A recent example has been certain non-political insults hurled at politicians. Calling them various mental disorders in a hateful tone doesn't hurt the politician because no one changes their vote because some armchair psychologist blathered on the internet, but helps stigmatize people with actual mental disorders, associating them with the negative personality traits of politicians we dislike even though those traits have nothing to do with the mental disorder. Unlike the fighter pilots, we aren't in a hurry. Nobody's gunning for us, we're not on the clock for a media company. We can stop and consider the ramifications of our retweets, including whether it's real or not and whether it's good or not. The latter is what takes over when it's not about fact, such as when people are retweeting a comedian tweeting a joke mocking someone we feel threatened by...and ignoring that the "joke" happens to be a derogatory slur against a minority. Things are only going to get better if we stop trying to be heard and start listening slowly and carefully before contributing.

Not sure if "truth is truth", and not sure if a something is more trustworthy just because someone has a lot of public credential studying it. That's because we do not live in a "closed world", and truth evolves as we discover facts or are willing to look at the world in new light. Ten years ago, a bunch of well studied scientists and doctor would have said fat is bad, but now we see the "truth" is more nuanced.

I think the best we can hope to do is spot outright lies and manipulations, such as people photoshopping or faking materials. But to spot "truth"? That's very difficult, and consequently spotting "un-truth" is also very difficult. Something could be true at some point in time that is no longer true, or true within a very specific context that a person without direct experience cannot differentiate. Spotting outright lies is probably doable. Spotting un-truth is probably counter productive.

I feel that a lot of people think truth is static, a given.

It's not. Truth is dynamic. It is an ongoing process, of corroborating and supporting and improving the confidence level of a given topic.

It's also very often forgotten that a fact doesn't simply exist. A fact does not exist without meta-facts -- facts about facts. There is always an error bar, or confidence level, an uncertainty about that fact. What is the history and origin of that fact?

When put in these terms, the process in the video pops out intuitively. Who said it? Why? Where did it come from? Is it reliable?

The hardest barrier to overcome is learning this process. If you take whole minutes to step through each tiny little article or tweet or sound bite you are exposed to, you'll never get anything done, right? You must try to do at least the tiniest step, so that in time, it becomes intuitive and automatic. Eventually, you can develop this skill to the same automatic level as a good journalist does.

Stay smart out there!

Destin, I feel that you are a Christian, and I want to speak to that part of things. There are many generations that have asked the same question Pilate asked of Jesus - "What is truth?" It's amazing to see that while it is more difficult for a modern day human to discern truth because of the sheer vastness of falsehood presented, the solution to these problems has been available for much longer.

Jesus Christ plainly declared that He is the truth (John 14:6). He told us that when the Comforter (the Holy Ghost, the Spirit of Truth) came He would guide us into all truth (John 16:7, 13). This Spirit of Truth can live inside of those who believe in Jesus Christ, but the world cannot receive it (John 14:17).

It is this Spirit of Truth, this Holy Ghost, this Jesus Christ inside you that will be the only absolute source of Truth. In the best of our logical attempts to discern truth, our feeble minds are led astray by the most cunning deceptions. As you mentioned here, there are points where (since there was some clear truth), you would conclude that the entire message was truth. This was the tactic the devil used from the beginning, and still is his tactic today. Consider even that the devil used scripture (which IS true) to tempt Jesus to do something that was NOT according to the truth (Matthew 4:6-7).

The part I mentioned about the Spirit of Truth living inside is very important, because you can actually know for certainty what is true and false. The Spirit of Truth (Jesus, who is truth) will "testify" or "witness" whether the thing you see or hear is of the truth. His Spirit inside you will either agree or disagree with the spirit of the thing you hear, and prevent you from being deceived. You only need listen to that still, small voice. I do believe that you have heard that voice yourself from time to time. I just encourage you to listen carefully.

The Bible does warn us that we aren't to believe everything without fact-checking, but the method the Bible implores us to use is not the natural means.
Beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits whether they are of God: because many false prophets are gone out into the world. 1 John 4:1

In essence, the simplest way to know truth is to ask the One who IS the truth. It's like looking at the source code. The point Katie made right off the bat is actually a similar method to what God expects us to do -- check where the information came from (except from a spiritual, not carnal standpoint). The difference in doing your own research and asking God is like the difference between trying to prepare puffer fish yourself at home, or trusting an expert chef of 20 years experience with the dish. With one, you can unintentionally poison yourself, where with the other, the guesswork is removed and you just get the delicious rewards.

Don't get me wrong. I'm not disagreeing with the information you presented here. This video will help someone to get a little closer to discerning truth from lies, and I commend you for helping in any way you can. The very fact that you have talked about the subject will encourage many to be more vigilant when they share information online.

As humans, we all need some help beyond our capacity to know certain things. This is why we learn from those who specialize in certain fields, and trust experts who know vastly more than we do in specific areas. I am grateful that we have a heavenly Father who knows literally everything and anything that can be known, and He is willing to tell us things we don't know (Jeremiah 33:3). IFCN is hosted by the Poynter Institute for Media Studies and funded, in part, by Google and foundations of leftist billionaires George Soros and Bill Gates. Soros donated $25 million to Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign. The Daily Mail reported that Clinton super-donor and eBay founder Pierre Omidyar is also backing the project.

In response to Facebook’s announcement, FrontPage said conservatives should consider ditching Facebook.

“In essence, Facebook is giving the partisan left free space on conservative news links. It’s also allowing them to undermine a conservative link while promoting their own agenda,” FrontPage said.

“It’s not quite censorship, but the partnership with left-wing partisan ‘checkers’ helps move it to the next step of barring sites outright. For the moment, Facebook has decided that you shouldn’t just be able to share links to what you’re interested in without the left getting a say.

“This is yet another reason for conservatives to rethink being on Facebook.”

The website reveals: “Poynter’s IFCN has received funding from the Arthur M. Blank Family Foundation, the Duke Reporters’ Lab, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Google, the National Endowment for Democracy, the Omidyar Network, the Open Society Foundations and the Park Foundation.”

Alexios Mantzarlis runs IFCN, which does not appear to have published any “fact-checking” articles since 2015.

However, a Feb. 16 Poynter “news” headline blasted “President Trump’s anti-media meltdown.”

From the very beginning, the story trashed the president for unveiling “an alternate universe … in which virtually every problem of his is a creation of the press.”

This video is such an asset to sorting through today's abundance of misinformation. It really is a lot harder to verify the veracity of information than one might think. Trusting sources with integrity and fidelity is the easiest stop gap, but it's challenging trying to avoid over reliance on the appeal to authority. Yet most people lack the time and the energy to check the hard evidence of every single claim.

Personally, I think there's some serious merit to enacting laws that curb blatant misinformation. It's rampant, toxic and incredibly dangerous. Yes, doing so infringes upon free speech. I'm of the mindset that expressing a personal opinion is a lot different from the mass dissemination of mis/disinformation. It'd take a lot of safeguards to ensure that censorship of falsehoods isn't vulnerable to misuse for political or personal gain. A national fact checking agency would require the same investigative integrity, independence and oversight as any other soundly executed law enforcement agency. But I think it'd be worth it for mitigating the rise of extremism, exploitation and propaganda.

Nah. Eff that noise. What you need to do is go to the source. When the media tells you this person says this or that, go see the video of that person actually saying it. When the media tells you white nationalist kids are shouting down a native American, go see the video. When the media tells you some individual is calling for the death of certain minorities and is sowing hatred, go see what he says. What you'll find is that the person said something completely different. Or that those kids were more akin to victims than aggressors. Or that the individual in question is the most lied about person on the face of the planet.
Do not trust someone else to draw conclusions for you. See with your own eyes, hear with your own ears, discuss your conclusions with your own mouth. Tell others what you see, understand what they're seeing. Have a conversation, have a debate. We're all biased in one way or another, and the only way we can discover that bias is by getting in touch with the people we disagree with, and understanding where the disagreement comes from. This is why the media is pushing so much of this progressive left rhetoric. Because at the root of that rhetoric lies censorship of competing ideas. The people they promote are very ideologically possesed and they are not interested in discussion, so they cannot identify their bias and can thus be easily manipulated. The people they disparage are being censored, kicked off media platforms like Twitter, Facebook, YouTube, and are thus unable to make their voice heard and are unable to defend themselves. Thus the media sows continuous disagreement, continuous conflict. And conflict is what the media feeds on. Don't play their game. Keep discourse alive. Protect free speech.

the first is blaming yourself, like he did (fairly mature, but not necessarily a method that shifts society)

the third is looking even deeper, blaming it on either society at large (society's culture), a group of people (scapegoating) (like the rich and powerful, or the immigrants or whatever. not saying they're equal, just saying it takes the same amount of skill, but not necessarily the same upbringing to find the difference. you would be called a hack if you did this) or the politics and infrastrucutre (system) (no, blaming it on the left or the right is not the same thing)

I find it's easier to see how obvious the fake news is from the conservative side, so I never really took any of that seriously. I also considered myself pretty liberal, especially since a lot of things considered liberal are common-place here in Canada. But I've noticed a lot of bullshit and dangerous rhetoric coming out of both sides now, especially on any "hot topic".

Gun crime for example. Liberal government and police chief of Toronto were pushing for stricter gun laws and regulations on licensed owners. They cited that over 50% of guns used in crimes are domestically sourced. Later reports found that these claims were 100% fabricated. Some of the outlets that republished the initial reports made redactions, but nobody cares about that. Especially considering the environment about anti-gun sentiments. This kind of thing is what Harry G. Frankfurt wrote about on his publication "On Bullshit". Whether you are for or against guns, any reasonable person can agree that misrepresenting the truth has no place in public discussions. On this topic, they brought up an emotional subject that everybody can get behind: ending gun violence. But then they mislead the people by misrepresenting the truth and used legal gun owners as a scapegoat even though statistically they're the least likely to commit violent crimes, especially since there's daily background checks for gun owners here in Canada.

Likewise, there's a lot of issues of a lack of transparency with the current government here in Canada. A lot of people were dissatisfied with the conservative Harper government, but this Trudeau government has had its share of issues. I believe in anthropomorphic climate change, but I don't trust the apocalyptic warning predictions so many people make. With more than 7 billion human beings on Earth we must be having an effect. But climate science is incredibly complicated and I think many advocates of reducing greenhouse gas emissions are understandably reluctant to admit how much we don't know. I say understandably because I think many people believe that in order to convince people to make changes they need to convince people the danger from climate change is imminent, severe, and certain. Therefore, if someone questions the data in a climate change report the typical response I see is the claim that "the science is settled" and that the person raising the question is a "climate change denier." What I remember learning in school is that science is never settled in that any theory must be considered open to revision if new evidence is revealed. If questions are raised about data those questions should be answered on the merits not dismissed as though blasphemous.


As I said I believe anthropomorphic climate change is real. What I don't believe is that climate scientist know with as much certainty as is claimed (by some) that by reducing emissions by X amount we will reduce global temperature increases by Y degrees. I think that the economic cost of some regulations to reduce emissions are more certain than the potential benefit of those regulations. What I worry about is that we may pass certain regulations that may make us feel better because "we are doing something about the problem" without any actual significant improvement. I don't know that they won't either. But when stolen e-mails reveal prominent climate scientists discussing the need to "hide the decline" in historical climate data it makes it harder to believe the world will end in 10 years if we keep eating hamburgers.

One big thing is the diversity of things to be knowledgeable about. New stories pop up everyday that dominate the news cycle, so if you try and research every story before deciding whether you believe it then you're perpetually behind the curve. The best way to break this pattern is to focus your efforts on one topic and resist chiming in on other ones. For example maybe you want to focus on Middle Eastern politics; research you do for one article will help you make determinations on the next one which will allow you to stay ahead of the influx of new stories. But that means that when there's a big story about some new gene therapy in China you need to either choose to ignore it or go research it and fall behind on new stories from the Middle East. A jack of all trades is a master of none, and there is too much propaganda and misinformation being thrown around for anyone to be able to get an accurate surface level view of a politicized subject. You have to dive deeper to be able to sort the facts from the lies, and that requires specialization and focus.

The OODA loop being cut short is also prevalent in business. Those that deliver minimally viable product (MVP) first get the credit for the accomplishment then move on to the next release cycle - never, "brooming up" afterwards. This creates multiple scenarios where cascading failures occur after authors have moved on - like the information sharing workflow you mention here.

As it turns out, unless we can figure out a better compensation model, selling people on their sense of obligation to add more work for less reward is contrary to human nature.

In the end, the douchebags win until we figure out how to fix the market.

I just searched for information on the Boeing 737 Max crash. Where could I get the best information from? A pilot posting online youtube videos. Not the big media not the journalists, not the official channels but an expert who is in the system, has flown similar airplanes and who has an open agenda (wants people to understand what is going on and thus not be afraid of flying + information for starting pilots). Sadly news is not like it was 30-40 years ago. The news was more fact-based. "Today the city council passed a local budget with an increase to x dollars. This is an increase of 3% from last year. The vote was 5 to 4." today the same event would easily be covered as "Today mayor rampage has activists worried about spending too much money." In the past, there was much less emotion. To be truly savy, you (Not somebody else) must go to "source documents". Find sources that are illegal for falsehoods, for example, published government agendas/records, court documents, that little white paper that nobody reads with your medication, CEO quarterly stockholder meetings.
A different example. Anything news or politics that makes you "feel" is a garbage news article. Anything with anon sources is garbage. Instead of reading an "Outrage" account of what happened at a local city council meeting. Take a minute and look up the agenda item from the council meeting web page. Then read the actual report attached to the item. Or if you have an issue with a State or Federal piece of legislation, read the bill. You will be surprised to learn what is actually in it. After doing this for a while you will learn that many times the title of the bill is actually the opposite of what it does and that most reporters are just repeating the lie from each other. Just having sources is not enough, just working for a large media company is not enough. You must look at the source and make your mind up for yourself and not continue to let someone else continue to do it for you.

That problem with assuming all bias is bad and all bias is equal is that in reality, some biases that are dismissive towards other positions on an argument/topic are evidence-based and some are not. The main concern when consuming news should not be quite so focused on the neutrality of that news source so much as their dedication to reporting on topics accurately. Blanket forced neutrality on all subjects is often seen as a proxy for the quality of a news organization whether or not the topic has two equal sides arguing, more than two sides of different levels of validness and evidence arguing (e.g. Economic theories) or topics where there is basically a correct evidenced based side and no other equal argument (e.g. LGBTQ people deserve human rights, people of all ethnic backgrounds are equally human, climate change is caused by humans and needs to be addressed, Vaccines don't cause autism, etc); this leads to too many new organizations using forced neutrality on all subjects as a way to retain their authority in the eyes of a public that has come to a point that they largely refuse to believe that many subjects have asymmetric sides, that believe that the middle ground in all arguments is in the center of two extremes. The reality is that a lot of topics are more like a sledgehammer than a see-saw; sure, they have a balance point that isn't at the very end of either side, but the balance point is clearly much closer to one end than the other. As soon as a new organization present it that way, in the actually accurate, reality and evidenced-based way the topic should be reported...they are labeled as 'biased' and 'partisan' because we've gotten to a point in our news where most people don't really let themselves be informed by good, accurate news reporting...they just use it to confirm their own beliefs in 'both-sides-ism' and anything that asserts that any topic has unequal sides is tossed out as having an agenda rather than perhaps themselves having an agenda to maintain their own worldview.

Expanding on the topic, I think the most pertinent question would be "why News Sucks". The problem lies in journalistic ethics going downhill with the race to be the first to report on something.
It was unavoidable, as our communication got faster and our brains craved that dopamine rush of instant gratification and confirmation bias. Yet nobody saw it coming.
But there's a lot you can learn by simply sitting and observing. So I came up with a few rules to determine what's believable and what's not.

1: Nobody's unbiased. NOBODY:
There's a huge demand for truly unbiased information and some people surf that wave while they can. But eventually, the mask always falls. So the trick is to keep track of who has whose bias. They think you forget. Don't.
I would much rather listen to somebody who clearly states his bias than somebody who pretends to be unbiased. Chances are, in today's climate, that the biased person is clearly aware that's just his opinion while the "unbiased" is pushing a narrative.

2: Wait 48-72 hours until all details come out:
This is the OODA loop Destin described, so i won't expand much further except from the fact that you can learn a lot by "sitting and observing" in those first 48 hours. You can quickly pick up who's pushing a narrative by how fast they jump the gun. Those are the media you SHOULD NOT thrust, at least as an unbiased source.

3: Buzzfeed is cancer:
By that, I don't mean it's full of far left activists pretending to be journalists. I mean that the Buzzfeed business model is the epitome of this problem. You see, Buzzfeed pays writers by article rather by a fixed wage or by how much traffic to the site it generates. It's entry level "journalism" for overgrown children fresh off college trying to make ends meet rather than building a name for themselves. That's why they don't even bother putting a picture of themselves besides their name on the top of the article. Buzzfeed business model encourages trash articles to generate clickbait and hateclick traffic, and that's all you're going to get with sites with the business as theirs. They started this clickbaiting culture, thus the dabacle of integral journalism.

4: NOBODY. IS. UNBIASED:
I can't stress this enough. Not even Mediawise. It's a "who watches the Watchmen?" question. Today, everyone's got a social media profile. So make use of that name besides the article you just read and do the 2+2. Some even have a direct link to their social media profile(s). You can marry this to Rule #2 and #5 to great effect.

5: Twitter is cancer:
You have everything that's wrong with journalism crammed into a more vapid, 288 character limit platform. Twitter is basically Buzzfeed³.

6: Nobody cares what you think:
This is exactly why you should think before you share something. I've always lived my life through Plato's guideline "the wise man has something to say. The fool needs to say something". So instead of caving in to the dopamine rush of the likes you're going to receive, think you're just promoting something for free. Personally, I don't replicate any news or opinion articles unless it's a reflection I find particularly interesting from one of my friends or from myself. My social media profile has very little content and what little I post is just either something I find funny, a nice picture (that may or may not include photos of my cats) obscure music I stumbled upon and the rare political takes are when there's something so blatantly wrong in the collective's mindset that I can't help but make fun of them.

In the end, I must repeat.
"The wise man has something to say. The fool has to say something".

10:00 “Read the entire article. They care more about views and clicks than telling you the truth.”

Every time I read something on the BBC I discover juicy nuggets of information in the final two sentences that unsettle their entire narrative. You also have to pay attention to word selection and usage. Just changing a word or phrase can alter the reader’s perception. I get a lot of, “What???” comments when I point these things out. Contrary to what you are told in this, the first minutes of a story breaking often includes important information that gets swept under the rug as the narrative is developed. Often the political and philosophical biases are written at the beginning of a news story then facts, or misrepresentations thereof, pieced together to fit their view. Postmortem, well fact checked articles are usually the most reliable but if you have well tuned antennas you strip away the agenda and still get a moderate idea of what actually happened.

Of course, there’s always being connected to the people in your own local community and taking care of them which will likely be a better use of your time. Attending the “Church of News Room” has not made much useful change in the world.

People lie. ALL people habitually lie. You do. I do. Even journalists do. When news happens, the reported news is generally just bullshit. Clickbait. Useless pseudo-news. Wait a few days, then look for news about the topic you're interested in. And then check where the news is from, who wrote it, verify it to the best of your abilities and research the topic at hand.

To me there's two kinds of "true". One is something I can verify, that multiple reputable researchers, multiple renowned experts in their field etc.pp claim to be true (and the like - it's a looooong list of conditions).
The other is "conditional truth". Something I believe to be true, but have no way (or interest) to verify. This latter truth is one I would not base important decisions on, and isn't one I'd spout as truth to anyone.

I appreciate the effort, but I don't think those steps are adequate. First off, being skeptical of only names you don't recognize just further entrenches you in your echo chamber. The lady you're working with there has a positive reaction when she sees the subject matter was written about by outlets like The Washington Post, despite the fact that they have been caught multiple times posting information without verifying it and putting their desire to push an ideology above their desire to share the truth (most recent example I can think of would be their Covington coverage). Furthermore, as Peter Boghossian and James Lindsay demonstrated last year, you can't even trust peer-reviewed "studies", because they are easy to fake, and ideologues within the education system are eager to corroborate anything that aligns with their biases. Their bogus study that got published about dog-humping in parks being a sign of rape culture could easily have been shared by The Huffington Post or other names that this lady would recognize. So, according to her standards, she would have recognized the name of The Huffington Post, and she would have gotten a link to a "study" that corroborates the information. So according to her steps in this video, it would have been fine to share that as truth, even though the authors have later revealed that it was 100% nonsense.
My final reservation about all of this is that we have already seen companies that set themselves up as the people that could find the truth amidst the misinformation (Snopes, Politifact, etc.), and every time, they wind up being just as biased and untrustworthy as the news outlets they are critiquing. I'd have to see a lot more from this MediaWise before I would believe that they are different.

Step1: "Who"s behind the information"
Step2: "What's the evidence"
Step3: "What do other sources say"

From this we can get a tactic to subvert the truth:

Step1: "Discredit the people (or group) publishing the information"
Step2: "Overwhelm the medium with contradictory evidence (even though it's fake)"
Step3: "Make sure lots of people share your story using your contradictory evidence."

I just now realize thanks to Destin that I've seen these 3 steps happen, I've seen interested groups subverting the truth using exactly these three steps.

My father worked at an oil refinery for 25 years. In that time there were several incidents, accidents, or just plain events that made it into the news, either just the local Paper (in Benicia) the local area (San Francisco Bay Area) or in the national news.
The number of times these events were reported accurately was.. . Zero.
Not once was an event reported accurately, There was always some important event not reported, or something that was that didn't happen was reported.
I was once interviewed as part of a story on an adaptive ski school I volunteered with. The interview was accurate (I was not misquoted) but there was quite a bit of the interview that was not included. But one story about me was completely made up. He described seeing me fall and coming up covered in powdery show. This never actually happened. But it was added simply to add flavor to the story. And as it was harmless (aside from making me seem a bit silly) I just let it go.
You don't really need to do so much research before you retweet. For one thing, no matter how careful you are, you will never know for sure if the story is true. In most cases the story won't be a total lie. But it may be told in a way that completely changes the way the story is seen.
For example, a guy that I know ran up to a woman sitting in an Cessna airplane, pulled her out and threw her on the ground, breaking her kneecap.
This makes my friend sound horrible, but nothing I said was untrue, while what I didn't say is very important. The airplane had just crashed and was on fire. The woman was sitting in the burning plane, frozen in panic.

There is one big potential pitfall here, implicitly trusting a "famous" (most people would equate "Well reputable" and "famous") source is a big problem too, and a problem harder to fact check ("undisclosed sources" + biases)...

Here's an example from my experience, one event I photographed in Russia back in 2012, a rather big and "controversial" event, the problem was that "reputable" media on one side wanted only images depicting their narrative (barely one side of the event), "reputable" media on the other side wanted only the images depicting the other side, both knew what they wanted before the events and published "image requests", and after the fact, no one wanted the whole picture... and this includes both western and Russian media. This affected me so strongly that I started refusing selling images if they did not reflect the whole picture and eventually decided that I no longer want anything to do with this field and started avoiding journalism and reportage altogether.

And yes, today I realize that the right thing to do at that time was to publish the whole shoot online as my own (subjective) view on the event and fight partial citations, but back then I was so stressed that I felt I do not even want to touch the topic... I still might do this as things are not getting better.

I have observed that the more I know about a subject, especially technical subjects, the more problems I detect in the information in news stories. This is just as true with "reputable" sources as with not well known sources. Also, just because a source is "reputable" does not mean that they check their own personal biases at the door when writing or reporting a story. I especially do not trust any "news" story that is presenting a "what you should think about this" angle. Just present the facts and I will make up my own mind thank you very much.

I think this solution is premised on an overly optimistic view of the problem at hand. They key assumption here is that we all agree on a set of "reputable" sources or what constitutes good evidence. That's not even close to being true. If you're a progressive, the words "Fox News"  and "reputable source" are oxymorons. If you're a conservative, news sources progressives like to read (not getting into a debate whether that makes them biased) like the Washington Post (said to be reputable in your video) are irreparably skewed. I think a dimmer view of the problem is more appropriate. People do follow the cycle you suggested, but they define "reputable sources" and "good evidence" differently (just read the comment section of this video). An even darker view is that this video may itself worsen the problem by encouraging people to cling more closely to their "reputable" news source in the verify step. I think this video should have given a lot of time to explaining what a "reputable" source is, but I understand your constraints as a non-partisan channel; it's hard to thread the needle. If you don't try to push people toward a common definition of "reputable", then you risk worsening the problem; if you do push, you might lose your audience. Tough all around Destin...

The Washington Post is trustworthy for several reasons. They adhere to a strict code of ethics, standards and practices which is readily available to the public. These standards specifically prioritize its mission to tell the truth and serve the public over the wishes of its owner. They have a reputation for accuracy and reliable sourcing which they guard closely and which is scrutinized closely by their competition. They accept responsibility for errors and publicize them adequately. The employees maintain a culture of journalistic integrity and they resist threats to that integrity.

To those who are commenting that all media is fake, you are wrong. The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and NPR are trustworthy for similar reasons. Each has biases which need to be taken into account, but the accuracy of their reporting continues to be strongly confirmed.

When I played Civilization V and got to the endgame for the first time, I was a bit confused to how they call the last era. It's not "Digital Era", "Space Era", or stuff like that. Instead it's called "Information Era," which is supposed to represent the timeline we are at today.


It didn't make sense to me until I observed how fast information is delivered, shared, and circulated online. So much so that, as you said, many outlets opt to not put their pieces through some sort of editorial. This waves of information then reaches people online that are already divided by platform-generated echo chambers that serves you content that it thinks you "like". Then these people form their own groups and perpetuate the same information among themselves over and over regardless of what really happened. Challenging the other camp will usually be met with hard resistance, thus discouraging discussion. If one people dislike you enough, they can dive through your social media account and internet footprints, and unearth embarrassing stuff about you. Get this - if people have more information on you, they can shut you down.


The news outlets, on the other hand, races to be the first to cover the story. They can't be arsed to fact-check, it's the information wild west after all. Only that instead of pistols, they draw their hottest take on even the most sensitive issue, usually with inflammatory headlines to catch your eye. The more eyes, the better.

When the "big names" and "reputable sources" get things wrong or outright lie, it throws an entire wrench into this equation. Ms. Byron's flawed base assumption is that those big names are by default trustworthy.

For me, it comes down to a Bayesian calculation. What has history proven to be true in the past, and what common elements of a story appear between many sources, big and small? Once I've evaluated the priors against the most consistent evidence, a better picture of the truth begins to appear. I'll likely never get the whole truth, but hopefully, I can get asymptotically close.

My technique is to start with the assumption that every article I read is coming from someone with no credibility. I then examine how much opinion is in the piece, and what the facts are. I then follow links to sources, decide if the sources are just being syndicated or if I need to check their sources too. It's a lot of work, so I pretty much give up and don't believe anything I read.

People should accept bias, not fear it. Methods like this can allow people to take in all information and apply the weight you give the information based on you ability to discern credibility. We shouldn’t seek information that confirms what we want to be true. We should take it all in and determine what’s worth holding on to... imo
